Award.AwardTitle: Research in Engineering Self-Efficacy of Minority Students

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: This engineering education research project seeks to create a theoretical basis that can be used to guide interventions to engage under-represented students in engineering and build their self-efficacy. The project, based on Social Cognitive Career Theory, will measure the self-efficacy of minority and majority students at predominately white institutions to determine the types of interventions that are best able to improve minority students' self-efficacy. Self-efficacy is a strong predictor of academic career choice and persistence. The knowledge gained from this investigation will be used to design a research-based intervention to improve minority students' self-efficacy. Dissemination of the results of this project can inform intervention and outreach strategies aimed at under-represented students at other institutions, and may have lasting impact on the number of engineers who come from currently under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
After decades of concerted effort and millions—maybe even billions—of dollars spent, the engineering profession remains predominantly white and predominantly male. The Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT) recognizes four distinct variables that influence a person’s career choice. These variables are: self-efficacy (belief that you are capable of performing the job), outcome expectations (a strong sense of a goal that will be achieved if you persist in the field), interests (how interesting or relevant you find the work), and environmental supports or barriers (are there people encouraging or hindering you along the path?). Of these variables, self-efficacy plays a significant role in academic career choice and persistence.

In this study, we examined the self-efficacy of minority engineering students at predominantly white institutions. Through the data analyzed in this study it was found that males and females had similar levels of Engineering Self-Efficacy and Sense of Belonging. White students had the highest Sense of Belonging and Black students had the lowest, with this difference between the two groups large and significant. Asian students had the lowest Coping Self-Efficacy compared to all other racial and ethnic groups. Further, for males and females who start with the same levels of self-efficacy, females had a higher probability of graduating from engineering compared to males. For White and Black students who started with the same level of self-efficacy, the White students were more likely to graduate compared to the Black students.

Based on a previous study to develop a sense of belonging among minority students in computer science programs, a brief intervention was developed and implemented in a first-year engineering course at one of the institutions. The intervention consisted of a brief video of a diverse group of students from the institution talking about times they felt they didn’t belong or times they struggled academically. They advised students to not let these temporary setbacks deter them from pursuing engineering. The video was shown in randomly selected sections of a first-year engineering course. The hope was that this intervention would be cost effective, easy to implement, and effective.

There was no short-term impact from the intervention; however, it appears that the students who watched the video were retained in engineering at a higher rate after three years when compared to those who did not view the video. This finding could have serious implications as we strive to diversify engineering.
